comment._content: Some of those faces - the eyes in particular - look like they have experienced things no one would like to see.

comment.author: 32104107@N03
comment._content: The photographer on this had to be incredible. This picture is downright flawless, and with the equipment they had back then. Wow. I'm freakin' amazed.

comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called THIRD PLANET/ Peoples, and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 68427449@N00
comment._content: I believe that the Light Horse Interchange on the M7/M4 (Sydney Australia) was named after the Light Horsemen, and that they also fashion Emu feathers on their hats to distinguish them from other units. If anyone has information relating to this could they please provide a link.

comment.author: 30115723@N02
comment._content: Hi Joriel "Joz" Jimenez - you can read a bit more about the use of emu plumes by the Australian Light Horse in this piece about the slouch hat or this article about emu plumes, both on the Australian War Memorial's website. According to the westlink M7 website, The Light Horse interchange is named for the Light Horse regiments. I hope that helps Liz, admin at the Australian War Memorial

comment.author: 74214992@N04
comment._content: i like this picture becuz i believe it says alot, these 8 men are from one unit, army whatever but in the background there are those native american shelters i forgot the name "To-pi" im not sure.  canes were big in those army days apparently, with 6 of the 8 having sticks with them. as i look at this picture i just cant help but to think of the poverty and the poorness in the days they were and with war trying to make its way in

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/74214992@N04] The tents in the distance are army issue bell tents of canvas on a central pole.
